issues.title: Add a structure to create the bearer
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
The following structure was defined in RFC8299:

```
                   +--rw bearer
                   |  +--rw requested-type {requested-type}?
                   |  |  +--rw requested-type?   string
                   |  |  +--rw strict?           boolean
                   |  +--rw always-on?          boolean {always-on}?
                   |  +--rw bearer-reference?   string

```

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Here is the updated structures

```
  +--rw bearers
  |  +--rw bearer* [id]
  |     +--rw id                  string
  |     +--rw description?        string
  |     +--rw customer-device
  |     |  +--rw device-id?   string
  |     |  +--rw location
  |     |     +--rw address?        string
  |     |     +--rw postal-code?    string
  |     |     +--rw state?          string
  |     |     +--rw city?           string
  |     |     +--rw country-code?   string
  |     +--rw requested-type?     identityref
  |     +--ro bearer-reference?   string
  |     |       {vpn-common:bearer-reference}?
  |     +--rw requested-start?    yang:date-and-time
  |     +--rw requested-stop?     yang:date-and-time
  |     +--ro actual-start?       yang:date-and-time
  |     +--ro actual-stop?        yang:date-and-time
```

issues.title: deal with multiple local subnets (local-address) - ip-connection list ?
issues.author: robric
issues.body: This case is an exception since most deployment rely on a single subnet per ac/logical link (best practice). However, it mandated by some deployments (example migration or legacy design).

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
For ac-ntw model, I think that having two ACs would be just fine to handle migration/merging cases. The ac-ref data node can help correlating ACs that are pointing to a single (service) AC.
```
  augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/sap:service/sap:sap:
    +--rw ac* [name]
       +--rw name                 string
       +--rw ac-ref?              ac-svc:attachment-circuit-reference
```

We may add some text to explain this.

It is clear that the BGP AS for the backbone is usually well known, however we may simplify the provisionning by just exposing it as a RO object.

issues.title: BGP authentication
issues.author: robric
issues.body:
We don't expose any authentication parameter such as key/secrets, although this is mandated by SPs. These parameters may be peer-specific, so it looks like a good idea to expose these in the bgp peer + peer-group.

(For now) we should also focus on exchanging keys/secrets and be agnostic of which authentication is used (legacy md5 2385 or recent/best practice rfc5925).

issues.title: bundling ACs (from Richard)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
More than the naming convention, we should also clarify the use case. There is - imho – a need for being able to grouping acs and being able to manipulate a set of ac (Think for example of a set of compute nodes attached to a TOR/Fabric or Cell Site Router). 
My thinking goes to something like “ac-bundle”, which can be a reference point for a connection to a service instead of the ac itself (think of a kind virtual interface). So this is more than a profile.

Example:

```
Comp1-------[  TOR  ]
Comp2---------|| |
Comp3----------| | 
...              |   
CompX------------| 

```
Assume you have sapX = CompX interface

We could get something like (spare me the approximative yaml, this is just for expressing the idea ).

```
ac-bundle:
name: aggregate-service-foo
l2-connection:
   cvlan-id: 100
ip-connection:
   ipv4:
     local-address: 192.168.1.1/24
     customer-addresses:
       address-pool:192.168.1.3-254

ac1
peer-sap sap1
ac-bundle-ref:
    aggregate-service-foo
ac2
peer-sap sap2
ac-bundle-ref:
    aggregate-service-foo
```

etc.

Basically, we’re getting an indirection between the service definition (rather static) and the connection (ac).
Next, with appropriate augmentation, we can anchor a service (L3SM, etc..) to a stable bundle identifier.  I am insisting on stable, since things move a lot in container ecosystem: you don’t really know in advance to which Node a service can be created, and you don’t know which address will be assigned. Here you may just add/remove your ac/sap to the bundle and you’re done.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
From @sbarguil:

> One of the doubts that I have from this approach, is how the Transport network controller should unwrap this global definition into network configurations. 
> 
> And the example you have provided is excellent. 
> 
> ac-bundle:
> name: aggregate-service-foo
> l2-connection:
>    cvlan-id: 100
> ip-connection:
>    ipv4:
>      local-address: 192.168.1.1/24
>      customer-addresses:
>        address-pool:192.168.1.3-254
>        assignation-policy: by-service
> 
> ac1
> peer-sap sap1
> ac-bundle-ref:
>     aggregate-service-foo
> ac2
> peer-sap sap2
> ac-bundle-ref:
>     aggregate-service-foo
> 
> My understanding is in this case:
> •	The controller needs to assign two interfaces from the network.
> o	How the controller determine what are the network interfaces it should reserve, in which node?
> 	The option I have seen from Med Example is the Bearer or the SAP. So this kind of requirements must always require a Bearer/SAP to be able to be applied on the network. Do you have any other idea about it?
> •	The controller needs to assign and reserve two IP addresses pool 192.168.1.3-254.
> o	How the controller determine what the free addresses of this pool? 
> o	As addresses can be reused across services do you think the requirement needs to have a service association? Or with bearer this can be inferred? In that case the bearer seems relevant too.
> o	In other case, for infra creation: Does the controller needs to read the whole network to determine which addresses are free in this pool.
> o	I understand If the size of the mask changed, for example is not /24 but /30 the controller should follow a different assignation rules. So maybe, we can consider add a leaf to determine IP address assignation pool behavior. 
> 	assignation-policy: by-service : it Means we expect this address is assigned in the context of the service attached.
> Regards,

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Leveraging the ac-group-profile and allowing for these profiles to be referenced by a service is one option to consider here but this would mean that the service has to manipulate two types of references. An alternate approach is to minimize the implications on the service and allow for an AC to inherit properties of another AC.    

Anyway, it would be great to have an appendix that basically echoes the example in this issues and clarifies the various questions from Samier.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: An example will be added in #111

issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
(1)	Request An AC over An Existing Bearer and Request An AC for a Known Peer SAP examples I can understand that the bearer-reference and the peer SAP id allows to know which is the PE port where the AC is attached. How can I know it in the One CE two ACs. It does not have any reference to the link. Should not it include a SAP?

issues.title: discuss the case of multiple CE reachable over a same AC
issues.author: robric
issues.body:
We may have multiple CE sitting on a same AC (e.g. the AC is the attachment to an L2VPN behind which we have multiple CEs).
We can identify each CE with a dedicated peer-sap.

If we want to manage the ip/routing configuration for a given CE,  the model seems not handy, because of the ac->sap binding. Indeed, we need to define several ACs/SAP  so we can attach the adequate ip/routing config. However, technically this is the same AC !

Should we have an intermediate level in the hierarchy ?
Should we come up with child/parent acs ?
Should change the definition of ac to something more generic (ac being one application) ?

This is definitely worth some discussion, so I am logging the issue.

comments.author: robric
comments.body:
Adding thought - should we clarify the concept of  multipoint ACs ?
We can have multiple L3 CEs aggregated on a single Switch which connects to the Network.
Technically, having a single L2 AC and multiple L3 AC... Or we're having  a point-to-multipoint AC.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @robric, I wonder whether this is fixed with the ac-bundle as well?

issues.title: Clarify the relation with composed VPN
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-evenwu-opsawg-yang-composed-vpn-03.txt

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The service-AC model does not make an assumption about the "internal" structure or even the nature or the service(s) that will be delivered over it. The customer does not have access to that view other than the ACes that are exposed. 

For example, draft-evenu has the following:

>                             +------v---------------+
>                             | Network Orchestrator |
>                             +----+---+-------------+
>                                  |   |
>                        +---------+   +-----------+
>                        |                         |
>                 +------+--------+         +------+---------+
>                 |Config manager1|         | Config manager2|
>                 +------+--------+         +------+---------+
>                        |                         |
>              +---------+-----------+  +----------+----------+
>              |      AS1 L2VPN      |  |      AS2  L3VPN     |
>   +-------+  | +------+   +------+ |  | +------+   +------+ |  +-------+
>   | Site1 +----+ PE11 +---+ PE12 +------+ PE21 +---+ PE22 +----+ Site2 |
>   +-------+  | +------+   +------+ |  | +------+   +------+ |  +-------+
>              +---------------------+  +---------------------+

The service-ac model can be used to provision the ACes to connect Site1 and Site2 as these are the only **visible*** one to the customer. If any configuration is required between PE12/PE21, this is handled at the network level since this will be viewed as a SAP(role-type=nni). 

evenu would be much more simple if it only manipulates ac-refs and focuses on the advanced service modelling specfic to the composed VPN case.

issues.title: Link back to the 3GPP NRM ObjectClass EP_transport
issues.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
issues.body: We are pushing confederated data model approach in CR for 3GPP NRM TS28.541. The idea is to have a ProxyClass NextHopInfo to hold Transport Network EPE-related information. Once this would be in place, the link back to the relevant NRM ObjectClass on 3GPP/ORAN subsystem e.g. EP_Transport is expected in order to navigate and to verify.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Thanks for the info. 

Do you foresee any impact on the service AC modelling effort? I naively assume that this will be on the 3GPP side to point to the AC model, not the other way around.

comments.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
comments.body:
3GPP SA5 folks anticipated the expectation of the link back no NRM. 
My feeling is that the simple link to the 3GPP NRM MIB tree of EP_Transport will do the job, so a little impact of "infrastructure" AC model is expected.

comments.author: boucadair

issues.title: compute-only flag for feasibility check
issues.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
issues.body: Following the corresponding flag in nbi-yang, we may consider adding "compute-only" flag to check that the ac with all its parameters may or may not be provisioned on EPE

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
It is reasonable to have such feasibility check. Please refer to https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/teas/A1ZIh6U2MSo5KAENu0X7Jh6dxtQ/.

However, I'm not sure yet a leaf is needed in the data model given that this is a functionality that is already provided by NETCONF for every configuration. FWIW, RFC6241 includes this parameter that can be used in an edit-config operation (using test-only would have the same effect):

```
test-option:  The <test-option> element MAY be specified only if
         the device advertises the :validate:1.1 capability
         ([Section 8.6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6241#section-8.6)).

         The <test-option> element has one of the following values:

         test-then-set:  Perform a validation test before attempting to
            set.  If validation errors occur, do not perform the
            <edit-config> operation.  This is the default test-option.

         set:  Perform a set without a validation test first.

         test-only:  Perform only the validation test, without
            attempting to set.
```

comments.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
comments.body: When we are expecting the implementation of single AC per multiple 3GPP slices such feasibility check may be not that important, but when slice implementation would be per AC, doing that check is important.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I'm not questioning the feasibility check. I agree that this is a good feature. My point is that this is redundant with what you can do "natively" with NETCONF.

comments.author: vlopezalvarez
comments.body: I'm not familiar with the feasibility check process. Is it a sync procedure in the API? I mean the server does not answer until there is not confirmation that the process is executed?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @vlopezalvarez, this is basically about "emulating" the processing of a request (that is, without putting it into effect if it succeeds).

comments.author: vlopezalvarez
comments.body:
Is there any pointer (RFC or draft) to understand which is the expected behaviour from the server point of view? I know my question is not related to the model, but I want to be sure we have a common view on which will be the workflow.

Typically there are two types of APIs, sync and async. Sync APIs would get the POST message with the "feasibility-check" and it will wait to answer until the feasibility check is done. This may take some time, depending on the network side and request complexity. Moreover, this blocks the server. On the other hand, Async APIs would get the POST and answer back immediately acknowledging the reception of the request (not the feasibility). It is up to the client to poll the API to obtain and update of the operation.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Is there any pointer (RFC or draft) to understand which is the expected behavior from the server point of view?

Apart the confirm/confirmed commit in NETCONF, I'm not aware of any other RFC that describes this explicitly.

comments.author: robric
comments.body:
I don't think we need a feaseability check for the AC itself, since it is not really meant to be used as standalone. 
Imho, this knob applies more for end-to-end services. For example, "compute-only" is part of Slice NBI data model. 
In this latter case - 5G slicing - the feaseability check is part of the slice request on which the AC is glued. 

Keep in mind that AC is more related to provide the right set connectivity information in a practical fashion (which is actually enforced together with the ad-hoc service slice). Additionally, there is no real computing here so the 'compute-only' naming would be confusing.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: double check restconf support and then decide.

issues.title: Link or a reference of nbi-yang service id(s), which are utilizing attachment-circuit-model  "infrastructure"
issues.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
FWIW: 
* We plan to have an ac-ref under the service itself. See the ac-glue module in the draft.

* We do also have access to a similar information at the network level: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-boro-opsawg-ntw-attachment-circuit/

>      augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/**sap:service/sap:sap**:
>        +--rw ac* [name]
>           +--rw name                 string
>           **+--rw ac-ref?              ac-svc:attachment-circuit-reference**
>           +--rw ac-profile* [profile-id]
>           |  +--rw profile-id    -> /nw:networks/network/ac-profile/name
>           +--rw description?         string
>           +--rw l2-connection
>           |  ...
>           +--rw ip-connection
>           |  ...
>           +--rw routing-protocols
>           |  ...
>           +--rw oam
>           |  ...
>           +--rw security
>              ...

Note that a SAP is defined as follows:

              +--rw service* [service-type]
                 **+--rw service-type                   identityref
                 +--rw sap* [sap-id]**
                    +--rw sap-id                      string
                 ...

the "service-type" can be set to l3vpn, l2vpn, vpn+, network-slice, vxlan, evpn, etc. 

I guess you want a read-only data node to also expose the service-types to the customer/application in the service model. Can you please elaborate what would be the typical usage? Thanks.

issues.title: missing link in  ietf-ac-svc:bearer to PE/CSR device ID
issues.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
issues.body: How to link "customer-device:device-id" to "node-id" or "ietf-node-id"?

comments.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN
comments.body: Do we see the necessity to mention optionally interface ID / LAD bundle ID on both ends?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> How to link "customer-device:device-id" to "node-id" or "ietf-node-id"?

@Ivan-Bykov-RBBN, I guess you mean the node ids in the provider's network as per:

```
   module: ietf-network
     +--rw networks
        +--rw network* [network-id]
           +--rw network-id            network-id
           +--rw network-types
           +--rw supporting-network* [network-ref]
           |  +--rw network-ref    -> /networks/network/network-id
           +--rw node* [node-id]
              +--rw node-id            node-id
```
If so, the provider's node-id is not exposed in the service model as this is internal to the provider. The mapping between a bearer and the PE is visible at the network model. That is defined in the companion network module (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-boro-opsawg-ntw-attachment-circuit/)

```
  augment /nw:networks/nw:network/**nw:node**/sap:service/sap:sap:
    +--rw ac* [name]
       +--rw name                 string
       `+--rw ac-ref?              ac-svc:attachment-circuit-reference`
       +--rw ac-profile* [profile-id]
       |  +--rw profile-id    -> /nw:networks/network/ac-profile/name
```

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Do we see the necessity to mention optionally interface ID / LAD bundle ID on both ends?

Not sure this is useful at service level because that information won't be useful for the provider to deliver the service. The current model allows to maintain multiple bearers bound to the same device-id without having to know if these bearers are locally bound to the same or distinct interfaces. The provider does not have that view anyway (unless the customer terminating point is managed by the provider).

If you have an example where the peer-sap/bearer-device-id are not sufficient to unambiguously identify an AC at the customer side, that would be helpful. Thanks, @Ivan-Bykov-RBBN

Listing here a few concerns regarding vrrp:
- technology specific (at the end of the day customer wants to consume a virtual IP NH/Gateway).

issues.title: Where to put the reusable groupings
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: where it makes sense to keep them in the ac-svc, while others in the common

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
FWIW, the current split approach of the groupings in common vs. svc is as follows: 
 * groupings/types that are reusable among ac-svc/ac-ntw/service models/network models are included in the ac-common
 * grouping that are usable only for service models are maintained in the ac-svc

issues.title: Comments from Kenichi Ogaki
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> My comments for draft-boro-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit-05 are as follows. I like the concept of this draft and the comments are subtle.
> 
> -Sec. 1.2
> "The mapping between an AC as seen by a customer and the network implementation of an AC is maintained by the network controllers"
> As a whole of this data modeling, I just don't like the term "local-address" and "customer-address".
> Who consumes this service model? If customer consumes, why the term "local" is used for "service provider" side, e.g. PE's address as "local-address"? Should be used for "customer" side?
> But, I don't strongly object, since it's just a definition.
> 
> -Sec. 4.2.2.1.
> I cannot imagine what "external-connectivity-identifier" is. If that corresponds to "Connection Identifier" of Appendix A.10., Sec. 4.2.2.1. should refer A.10. and add some explanations of the correspondence to A.10.
> 
> -Figure 18
> When we diversify an IP connection with two ACs, we commonly configure different IP address with different subnet to each AC.
> So, we should assign different IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, e.g. 192.0.3.1/30, to ac2 from ac1.
> Same for later, i.e. Figure 21, 23. 
> 
> -Figure 27, 28
> Following the diagram in Figure 27, ac2's CE is GW2. Then, CE-address, ac[name="ac1"]/ip-connection/ipv4/local-address should be 192.168.0.2.6 .
> 
> 
> -Figure 32
> If MD5 authentication is used, "md5-keychain" is necessary following the YANG tree, Figure 11.
> "authentication": {
>    "keying-material" {
>        "md5-keychain" : "nyxNER_c5sdn608fFQl3331d"
>      }
> }
> 
>         |     |     +--rw authentication
>         |     |     |  +--rw enable?            boolean
>         |     |     |  +--rw keying-material
>         |     |     |     +--rw (option)?
>         |     |     |        +--:(ao)
>         |     |     |        |  +--rw enable-ao?          boolean
>         |     |     |        |  +--rw ao-keychain?
>         |     |     |        |          key-chain:key-chain-ref
>         |     |     |        +--:(md5)
>         |     |     |        |  +--rw md5-keychain?
>         |     |     |        |          key-chain:key-chain-ref
> 
> 
> -Figure 25
> The 2nd bearer-reference's "ce1-network" should be "ce2-network"
>

issues.title: Add text to explain the rationale for the naming
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
(From Kenichi)

> My comments for draft-boro-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit-05 are as follows. I like the concept of this draft and the comments are subtle.
> 
> -Sec. 1.2
> "The mapping between an AC as seen by a customer and the network implementation of an AC is maintained by the network controllers"
> As a whole of this data modeling, I just don't like the term "local-address" and "customer-address".
> Who consumes this service model? If customer consumes, why the term "local" is used for "service provider" side, e.g. PE's address as "local-address"? Should be used for "customer" side?
> But, I don't strongly object, since it's just a definition.

[Med] We used “local-address” rather than “provider-address” (or similar) as we wanted to ease the mapping/translation of the service model into existing network models. For example, the mapping with L3NM is straightforward as the same name conventions are used. This is about internal mechanics, but we want to adhere to RFC8969 as much as possible. We will further insist on these considerations in the draft.

issues.title: Bearer Life Cycle Management
issues.author: sbarguil
issues.body:
The bearer contains all the data of the connectivity between Provider Edge and Customer Edge. The draft makes a first definition of the components of the bearer. 

In addition, the draft covers the **Top-Down** (from OSS Systems to SDN Controllers) approach where the inventory and network data is populated into the Network controllers using POST requests. However, there are scenarios where the information of the current network scenarios needs to be bulk into the Database of the network controller.

Massive loads from the NBI of the Controllers is a viable solution, however the requirement to automatically discover and audit the information in a button-up (from Network Elements to Controllers) scenario is also present. In this possible scenario there are some possible enhancements to includein the draft  as part of the bearer definition:

- What is the recommended protocol/mechanism used to pull this information from the Network.
- Is there any prefer protocol or polling process?
- How often this polling should be ordinarily done? Can it be adjusted? 
- Any recommendation of How to align differences between network and controller registers?

issues.title: oper-status
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
The main doubt we have received so far and “hot” topic is the oper-status management. 

•	How the oper-status should be used in service and node level. 
•	How are related if there are several vpn-nodes available. 
•	How node changes should be reflected in the whole service oper-status.

Here I have heard several options (combinations) and the implementations are following different patterns. 
So clarify the expected behavior its really necessary for the multivendor scenarios.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
@sbarguil, I think this can be clarified in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-boro-opsawg-ntw-attachment-circuit/. We do already have a good discussion on status in rfc9408 that we can further elaborate in the ntw-attachment.

See also https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/opsawg/NpLJPSFIljA3rGHT4gmgAj2f8lE/

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
@Med and @oscargdd, Do we have any suggested behavior for default values in the Network model? 

For instance, BFD has some default configuration values:

![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/13772485/c0be954b-2699-4d8c-b51c-66f756ec915d)

If a GET request is sent to the controller asking for the Net-Access details, the RESTCONF server can report the 'default-values' unless the 'with-default-values' & trim option is supported.

Hence, if the controller reports all values, including default values:

- Do those values mean the controller sent them to the network?
- How can we differentiate between what was sent to the network and what is default?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Default handling can be controlled as depicted below: 

![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/15671127/b999ca74-1a70-456d-90f7-5843dfa2296b)

and
![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/15671127/acf4ea71-b883-4440-be1a-32526e0e6329)

There might be cases where the server supports default values that are not aligned with the spec. The client should at least retrieve these values and compare them with its interpretation once. Then, it can set the trim/explicit filters to control which data to be reported by a server.

Data nodes that are not reported in the explicit mode but was reported with report-all are those that include a default value not explicitly set by the network. 

Here is an example:
![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/15671127/ec613e37-2d93-421e-8cf8-54d41a69c2bb)

![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/15671127/1fc49531-498f-42c7-9638-3942c0e0edd0)

![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/15671127/6e9d617d-e471-4015-b4f4-29d43e0c646f)

issues.title: VXLAN AC
issues.author: robric
issues.body:
I have a few points regarding the provisionning of VXLAN-based AC. The UC to automate the config of VXLAN-based services between PE and CE. The bearer is the IP underlay connectivity configured (we can assume it is configured with proper control plane/MP-BGP).

```
CE--------------------PE---- core network --- PE
 <------MP-BGP------->
CE =======VXLAN======(VRF)--mpls or srv6----(VRF)
```

Firstly, I don't get the organisation since it is under  L2-service, while VXLAN can be L3.
```
        |  +--rw encapsulation
        |  |  +--rw type?              identityref
        |  |  +--rw dot1q
        |  |  |  +--rw tag-type?   identityref
        |  |  |  +--rw cvlan-id?   uint16
[...]
        |  +--rw (l2-service)?
        |  |  +--:(l2-tunnel-service)
        |  |  |  +--rw l2-tunnel-service
        |  |  |     +--rw type?         identityref
[...]
        |  |  |     +--rw vxlan

``` 
Next,  the ac-svc data model must help with the configuration of additional VRF with key attributes such as VNI and a RT. RD should imho be added (optional) if some folks want to manage the  rd namespace and avoid collisions.

So we would have something like this with these attributes - we can keep also peer-ip-address is some folks want to automate the MP-BGP bringup.
```
    +--rw vxlan
       +--rw vni-id             
       +--rw route-target?         
       +--rw route-distinguisher?
       +--rw peer-ip-address* 
```

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
**VXLAN Scenario Covered**: The specific VXLAN scenario covered in the data model involves the binding of VXLAN interfaces to network-instances, analogous to how subinterfaces are linked to network-instances. This approach mirrors the treatment of tunnel technologies as subinterfaces within the LxNM data model. Placing VXLAN at the same level of Net-Access/connection configuration ensures a unified and comprehensive provisioning process.

**RTs and RDs Control**: I appreciate your insight regarding RTs and RDs. These elements have been seamlessly integrated into the Layer 2 Network Model (L2NM) to facilitate the management of tunnels and their associated attributes.
![image](https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/assets/13772485/c7dc18c5-b786-44a9-9ccd-54b91687176e)


The Attachment Circuit (AC) provisioning process, which is a vital aspect of ensuring service connectivity, should ideally work in conjunction with the L2NM to provide full control over the VXLAN or EVPN setup. This combination allows us to holistically address both connectivity and advanced customization needs.

comments.author: robric
comments.body:
Hi Samir, thanks for your feedback. 

We need to dig on "work in conjunction with L2NM" since this can be either explicit (having request meddling both data models) or implicit (the request is for an ac + a given vpn/slicing service model which is translated to L2NM).  We really don't need to full control of VXLAN/EVPN.

Another point (small digression), VXLAN can be L3...  I am wondering how much it fits with L2NM. I haven't fully run the gap analysis for routed VXLAN (Type 5 EVPN), but the minimal set of resources here might actually just work (VNI+RT  for T5 and... then re-use the set of L3 plumbing that is already defined  -this relates to IPAM - ) => I can come with examples here if you like

issues.author: Ivan-Bykov-RBBN

1. There is a mismatch of 3GPP NRM TS-28.541 Clause  6.3.35 LogicalInterfaceInfo and bearer yang tree:
3GPP NRM: 
LogicalInterfaceInfo.portName? string

        no port info 

2. A mismatch of 3GPP NRM TS-28.623 Clause A 2.2.2 IOC ManagedElement and bearer yang tree:
3GPP NRM: 
        locationName? string 
AC DM:
        |  |  +--rw location
        |  |     +--rw location-name?  string

3. Missing parameters in bearer DM:

- crossing id and fiber parameters
- microwave line id with port id
- l2 or l3 leased service id
- id of additional switch in the middle, not controlled by "customer" or "provider"
- service may use more than one Bearer. It may be LAG, dual-homing, FHRP, EVPN - examples of L2/L3 services running on multiple bearers at the same time

issues.title: ietf-ac-ntw: Augmenting "node" instead of “sap”
issues.author: lana-wu
issues.body:
This **ietf-ac-ntw** can be used for provisioning of ACs prior or during service provisioning.
For the two scenarios:
1. Before service provisioning, the SAP may not exist. Should the **AC list** be extended under "node" instead of "sap"?
2. During service provisioning, SAP is created with services, and AC list reference can added to "sap".

Suggested to change:
**OLD**
 augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/sap:service/sap:sap: 
       +--rw ac* [name]

**NEW**
 augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node
       +--rw ac* [name]

 augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/sap:service/sap:sap: 
      +--rw ac-ref*

issues.title: For “ietf-ac-ntw”, can 'Attachment Circuits'-as-a-Service be used as a service type?
issues.author: lana-wu
issues.body:
Can 'Attachment Circuits'-as-a-Service be a service type?

```
    augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node:
              +--rw service* [service-type]
                 +--rw **service-type**                   identityref
                 +--rw sap* [sap-id]
```

As defined in RFC9408, 'service-type' are all connectivity services:

   A SAP network topology can be used for one or multiple service types
   ('service-type').  Examples of supported service types are as
   follows:

   *  L3VPN [RFC4364],

   *  Virtual Private LAN Service (VPLS) [RFC4761][RFC4762],

   *  Virtual Private Wire Service (VPWS) [RFC8214],

   *  BGP MPLS-Based Ethernet VPN [RFC7432],

   *  VPWS in Ethernet VPN [RFC8214],

   *  Provider Backbone Bridging Combined with Ethernet VPN (PBB-EVPN)
      [RFC7623],

   *  VXLAN-based EVPN [RFC8365],

   *  Virtual Networks [RFC8453],

   *  Enhanced VPN (VPN+) [I-D.ietf-teas-enhanced-vpn],

   *  Network slice [I-D.ietf-teas-ietf-network-slices],

   *  SDWAN [I-D.ietf-bess-bgp-sdwan-usage], and

   *  Basic IP connectivity.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> In the bearer definition, will we mandate the bearer-reference must be used when the AC is created? 

Not in the current version, as we also allow to identify an AC by its peer-saps.  Please see https://boucadair.github.io/attachment-circuit-model/draft-boro-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit.html#name-request-an-ac-for-a-knwon-p 

> If the AC may be a physical interface, what is the intent of a bearer?

The AC is not physical. Here is the proposed definition in #32

>  For that data transfer to take place within the provider network, it is assumed that adequate setup is provisioned over the links that connect customer terminating points and a provider network so that data can be successfully exchanged over these links. The required setup is referred to in this document as Attachment Circuits (ACs), while the underlying link is referred to as "bearers".

"bearer" is a actually a key definition. We should double-focus on this one imho. We might have a call together just for this part.

A few comments meanwhile:
- I would use a different word than attachment (since we use attachment circuit): maybe connection to a customer site.
- you say "(they cover layer 1 and Layer 2)". I think the "and", is confusing since people may think L2 config (e.G. a vlan) is mandated.  This is more a "or", but we should actually phrase differently.
- add example (i.e. identifier of phyiscial connection)

I made some first tweaks to address your comments. I'm still not happy with the current version, though.

I'm hesitating adding a pointer to https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6788 to show an example of line identification.

Let's discuss by phone.

```suggestion
: The operator allocates a unique bearer reference to identify a bearer within its network (e.g., customer line identifier). Such a reference can be retrieved by a customer and used in subsequent service placement requests to unambiguously identify where a service is to be bound.
```

In some cases, the identification of the site is not sufficient. We need to have the identification of the device(s) that will terminate an AC on the customer site. Think about the Network Functions attachment cases or peer ASBRs.

pulls.title: Internal service structure is hidden to AS customer
pulls.author: boucadair

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Are “ethernet interfaces” in the definition are physical interfaces/physical links? To me, the confusion hers is: In the slice framework definition, the AC can be a physical link or a logical link. If AC can be a physical link, then AC = bearer?

@lana-wu, I fail to see where in the slice framework, it is said that an AC=a physical link. FWIW, here is the full AC definition:

>    Attachment Circuit (AC):  A channel connecting a CE and a PE over
>       which packets that belong to an IETF Network Slice service are
>       exchanged.  An AC is, by definition, technology specific: that is,
>       the AC defines how customer traffic is presented to the provider
>       network.  The customer and provider agree (through configuration)
>       on which values in which combination of layer 2 and layer 3 header
>       and payload fields within a packet identify to which {IETF Network
>       Slice service, connectivity construct, and SLOs/SLEs} that packet
>       is assigned.  The customer and provider may agree on a per {IETF
>       Network Slice service, connectivity construct, and SLOs/SLEs}
>       basis to police or shape traffic on the AC in both the ingress (CE
>       to PE) direction and egress (PE to CE) direction.  This ensures
>       that the traffic is within the capacity profile that is agreed in
>       an IETF Network Slice service.  Excess traffic is dropped by
>       default, unless specific out-of-profile policies are agreed
>       between the customer and the provider.  As described in
>       Section 5.2 the AC may be part of the IETF Network Slice service
>       or may be external to it.  Because SLOs and SLEs characterise the
>       performance of the underlay network between a sending SDP and a
>       set of receiving SDPs, the traffic policers and traffic shapers
>       apply to a specific connectivity construct on an AC.

WLAN, 4G, 5G, etc.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The 'specific-provisioning-profiles' container ({{gp-svc-tree}}) can be used by a service provider to maintain a set of reusable profiles. The profiles definition are similar to those defined in {{!RFC9181}}, including: Quality of Service (QoS),  Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD), forwarding, and routing profiles. The exact definition of the profiles is local to each service provider. The model only includes an identifier for these profiles in order to facilitate identifying and binding local policies when building an AC.
```

```suggestion
The 'l2-connection' container ({{l2-svc-tree}}) is used to configure the relevant Layer 2 properties of an AC including: encapsulation details and tunnel terminations. For the encapsulation details, the model supports the definition of the type as well as the Identifiers (e.g., VLAN-IDs) of each of the encapsulation-type defined. For the second case, attributes for pseudowire, Virtual Private LAN Service (VPLS), and  Virtual eXtensible Local Area Network (VXLAN) tunnel terminations are included. This structure relies upon the common groupings defined in {{!I-D.boro-opsawg-teas-common-ac}}.
```

```suggestion
In addition to static routing, the module supports BGP, OSPF, IS-IS, and RIP. It also includes a reference to the 'routing-profile-identifier' defined in {{sec-profiles}}, so that additional constraints can be applied to a specific instance of each routing protocol.
```

```suggestion
As shown in the tree depicted in {{rtg-svc-tree}}, the 'routing-protocols' container defines the required parameters to enable the desired routing features for an AC. One or more routing protocols can be associated with an AC.  Such routing protocols will be then enabled between a PE and the customer terminating points. Each routing instance is uniquely identified by the combination of the 'id' and 'type' to accommodate scenarios where multiple instances of the same routing protocol have to be configured on the same link.
```

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body:
Thank you for the review. Please find some edits based on your own review.

Let's try to find a better name for CTP. Suggestions are welcome

comments.body:
```suggestion
* A Customer Terminating Point (CTP) may be a physical device or a logical entity. Such a logical entity is typically a software component (e.g., a virtual service function that is hosted within the provider's network or a third-party infrastscruture). A CTP is seen by the network as a peer SAP.
```
virtual SF is no more than a software component.

```suggestion
* The same AC service request may include one or multiple ACs that are bound to a single CTP or a plurality of CTPs. 
```

```suggestion
* A single AC (as seen by a network provider) may be bound to one or multiple peer SAPs (e.g., CTP#1 and CTP#2 are tagged as peer SAPs for the same AC). For example, and as discussed in {{!RFC4364}}, multiple CTPs (CEs) can be attached to a PE over the same attachment circuit. This is typically implemented if the layer 2 infrastructure between the CTP and the network provides a multipoint service.
```

```suggestion
* The customer may request protection schemes where the ACs bound to a customer endpoints are terminated by the same PE (e.g., CTP#3), distinct PEs (e.g., CTP#34), etc. The network provider uses this request to decide where to terminate the AC in the network provider network and also whether to enable specific capabilities (e.g., Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP)).
```
To better cover the diversity placement request (same pe, same PoP, same bearer, etc.) + protection over an AC.

```suggestion
The procedure to provision a service in a service provider network may depend on the practices adopted by a service provider, including the flow put in place for the provisioning of advanced network services and how they are bound to an attachment circuit. For example, the same attachment circuit may be used to host multiple connectivity services. In order to avoid service interference and redundant information in various locations, a service provider may expose an interface to manage ACs network-wide. Customers can then request a bearer or an attachment circuit to be put in place, and then refer to that bearer or AC when requesting services that are bound to the bearer or AC.
```

```suggestion
Let’s consider the example of an eNodeB (CTP) that is directly connected to the access routers of the mobile backhaul (see {{enodeb}}). In this example, two ACs are needed to service the eNodeB (e.g., distinct VLANs for Control and User Planes).
```

pulls.title: rationale for keeping some reusable groupings in the ac-svc
pulls.author: boucadair

comments.body:
```suggestion
Like the L2SM, the L3SM {{?RFC8299}} addresses certain AC-related aspects. However, the L3SM structure does not sufficiently address layer 2 provisioning requirements. Additionally, the L3SM is primarily designed for conventional L3VPN deployments and, as such, has some limitations for instantiating ACs in other deployment contexts (e.g., cloud environments). For example, the L3SM does not provide the capability to provision multiple BGP sessions over the same AC.
```

```suggestion
Also, the document specifies a set of reusable groupings. Whether other service models reuse structures defined in the AC models or simply include an AC reference is a design choice of these service models. Utilizing the AC service model to manage ACs over which a service is delivered has the advantage of decoupling service management from upgrading AC components to incorporate recent AC technologies or features.
```

```suggestion
Connectivity services are provided by networks to customers via dedicated terminating points, such as Service Functions {{?RFC7665}}, customer edges (CEs), peer Autonomous System Border Routers (ASBRs), data centers gateways, or Internet Exchange Points. A connectivity service is basically about ensuring data transfer received from or destined to a given terminating point to or from other terminating points within the same customer/service, an interconnection node, or an ancillary node. The objectives for the connectivity service can be negotiated and agreed upon between the customer and the network provider. To facilitate data transfer within the provider network, it is assumed that the appropriate setup is provisioned over the links that connect customer terminating points and a provider network, allowing successfully data exchanged over these links. The required setup is referred to in this document as Attachment Circuits (ACs), while the underlying link is referred to as "bearers".
```

```suggestion
This document specifies a YANG service data model ("ietf-ac-svc") for managing attachment circuits that are exposed by a network to its customers, such as an enterprise site, a network function, a hosting infrastructure, or a peer network provider. The model can be used for the provisioning of ACs prior or during advanced service provisioning (e.g., Network Slice Service).
```

```suggestion
: The "admin-status" attribute is typically configured by a network or operator to indicate whether the network element or service is enabled, disabled, or subjected to additional testing or pre-deployment checks. These additional options, such as 'admin-testing' and 'admin-pre-deployment', provide the operators the flexibility to conduct additional validations on the bearer before deploying services over that connection.
```

```suggestion
: It is important to note that the "admin-status" attribute should remain independent of the "oper-status". In other words, the setting of the intended administrative state (e.g., whether "admin-up" or "admin-testing") MUST NOT be influenced by the current operational state. If the bearer is administratively set to 'admin-down', it is expected that the bearer will also be operationally 'op-down' as a result of this administrative decision.
```

```suggestion
: The "oper-status" of a service reflects its operational state as observed at a particular bearer. As a bearer can be used fir multiple services, the operational status should only reflect the status of the bearer connection. The network-level service status can be retrieved using specific   network models, e.g., those listed in {{ Section 7.3 of !RFC9182}} or
{{Section 7.3 of !RFC9291}}.
```

```suggestion
: To assess the service delivery status for a given bearer comprehensively, it is recommended to consider both administrative and operational service status values in conjunction. This holistic approach  allows a network controller or operator to identify anomalies effectively.
```

```suggestion
: For instance, when a bearer is administratively enabled but the "operational-status" of that bearer is reported as "op-down", it should be expected that the "oper-status" of services transported over that bearer is also down. If these status values differ, a trigger to detect an anomaly.
```

> Is this for the multi-homing scenario?

Yes. The reasoning is the same as why we have multiple site-network-accesses and vpn-network-accesses for the same VPN instance.

> perhaps we can also add an AC leaf node to site-network-accesses

Do you mean under "site-network-access", not "site-network-access**es**"?

Adding a leaf under "*-network-access" may be helpful to correlate explicitly the various concepts. So, far we only rely on implicit references. For example, RFC9408 says the following: 

>       For example, 'sap-id' may be the VPN network access identifier
>       defined in Section 7.6 of [RFC9182]. 

or 
>    If they are compatible, the 'attachment-id' value can be used as the
>    VPN network access identifier in an L3NM "create" query.

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body:
Thanks for the clarification.

> > perhaps we can also add an AC leaf node to site-network-accesses
> 
> Do you mean under "site-network-access", not "site-network-access**es**"?
Yes. 
> 
> Adding a leaf under "*-network-access" may be helpful to correlate explicitly the various concepts. So, far we only rely on implicit references. For example, RFC9408 says the following:
> 
> > ```
> >   For example, 'sap-id' may be the VPN network access identifier

> > ```
> 
> or
> 
> > If they are compatible, the 'attachment-id' value can be used as the
> > VPN network access identifier in an L3NM "create" query.

I was thinking that if the ACs are created before the LxNM, the LxNM can directly reference the AC network instance rather than creating "*-network-access" .

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The pending comment is now moved to https://github.com/boucadair/attachment-circuit-model/issues/142

> I was thinking that if the ACs are created before the LxNM, the LxNM can directly reference the AC network instance rather than creating "*-network-access" .

This is what is supported by the current version.

```suggestion
CE-PE routing using BGP is a common scenario in the context of MPLS VPNs and is widely used in enterprise networks. In the example depicted below, the CE routers are customer-owned devices belonging to an Autonomous System (ASN 65536). CEs are located at the edge of the provider's network (PE, or Provider Edge) and use point-to-point interfaces to establish BGP sessions. The point-to-point interfaces relies upon a physical bearer (Line-113) to reach the provider network.
```

```suggestion
               "local-address":"192.0.2.1",
```
use documentation address block as defined in [RFC 5737](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5737)

```suggestion

```

```suggestion
                        "peer-as":65536,
```
Use ASN reserved for documentation defined in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc5398/

```suggestion
                     "remote-address":"192.0.2.2",
```

{{cloud-parent-infra}} describes the physical infrastructure on which attachment circuits are provisioned. The compute nodes (customer) are attached to the provider infrastructure via a set of bearers (i.e., "compute-XX-nicY"). ```

## BGP Peering

```suggestion
To facilitate forwarding between the interconnected networks, BGP peering sessions are established between the participating networks. BGP is used to exchange routing information and reachability announcements between those networks.
```

```suggestion
As depicted in {{bgp-peer-network}}, each AC represents the link between the two networks. The AC configuration includes parameters such as interface settings, VLAN configuration (if applicable), and any additional settings required for connectivity.
```

```suggestion
Once the ACs are established, BGP peering sessions are configured between the routers of the participating networks. BGP sessions are established over the ACs, allowing the routers to exchange routing information. BGP peering configuration includes parameters such as neighbor IP addresses, AS numbers, authentication settings (if required), etc.
```

```suggestion
In this scenario, multiple networks, each represented by a Network Element (NE), connect to other networks or a Network Access Point (NAP) for interconnection purposes. Each network connects to each other through one or more ACs.
```

```suggestion
This document specifies a YANG service data model ("ietf-ac-svc") for managing attachment circuits that are exposed by a network to its customers, such as an enterprise site, an SF, a hosting infrastructure, or a peer network provider. The model can be used for the provisioning of ACs prior or during advanced service provisioning (e.g., Network Slice Service {{?RFC9543}}).
```

```suggestion
The 'security' container specifies a minimum set of encryption-related parameters that can be requested to be applied to traffic for a given AC. Typically, the model can be used to directly control the encryption to be applied (e.g., Layer 2 or Layer 3 encryption) or invoke a local encryption profile (see  {{sec-profiles-desc}}). For example, a service provider may use IPsec when a customer requests Layer 3 encryption for an AC.
```

```suggestion
A request to create a bearer may include a set of constraints ("placement-constraints") that are used by a controller to decide the network terminating side of a bearer (e.g., PE selection, PE redundancy, or PoP selection). Future placement criteria ("constraint-type") may be defined in the future to accommodate specific deployment contexts.
```
